title: Dr.¬†LLM, help me
text: Doctor Cat

title: Dr.¬†LLM, help me
text:
Preliminary Thoughts
Some people really seem to trust very deeply into AI in terms of scientific knowledge, despite the fact that AI is being built off of solely human knowledge, or even human misinformation being available off the internet.
So I wanted to see, what is the accuracy that LLMs have in diagnosing someone of their illness? I presume that due to user‚Äôs very positive and deferential attidues towards AI, using LLMs as a diagnostic tool may already be a reality.
I also am continuing my comparison of different LLM capabilities in medical subjects, so again I am testing this ability between Gemini 2.5 Pro and ChatGPT-5.

title: Dr.¬†LLM, help me
text:
Experiment: Diagnose My Illness
I decided to go with laryngitis as my test illness, as it is a common condition (almost all Americans will experience acute laryngitis at least once in their life‚Ä¶) yet also differentiated from the ultra common conditions such as the common cold and also more specific in symptoms than more general conditions such as diarrhea-related illness.
I used the laryngitis symptoms available on the Google search page to craft my prompt.
Prompt:  I am experiencing the following symptoms:  * a cough  * dryness and soreness of the throat  * congestion  * fever  * hoarse voice 
What is your diagnosis of my illness? Please only mention ONE illness and explain why you chose this illness in a succinct paragraph. Please provide your own confidence in its accuracy in percentage form as well.
ChatGPT-5‚Äôs Response
Based on your symptoms of cough, throat dryness and soreness, congestion, fever, and hoarseness, the most likely diagnosis is influenza (the flu). This illness commonly presents with fever and systemic symptoms such as fatigue, alongside respiratory involvement that includes cough and congestion. The hoarse voice and sore throat are consistent with irritation of the upper respiratory tract that often accompanies flu infections. While other conditions like the common cold or laryngitis could cause some of these symptoms, the presence of fever strongly points toward influenza rather than a milder viral infection. Confidence: ~75%
Gemini 2.5 Pro‚Äôs Response
Based on your symptoms, the most likely illness is acute Laryngitis.  The defining symptom of laryngitis is a hoarse voice, which is caused by the inflammation of the larynx (voice box). The other symptoms you are experiencing, such as a cough, sore throat, congestion, and fever, are classic signs of a viral upper respiratory infection, which is the most common cause of acute laryngitis. This single diagnosis specifically accounts for all your listed symptoms, with the hoarseness being the key indicator that points to the larynx as the primary site of inflammation.  My Confidence: 80%  Disclaimer: I am an AI assistant and not a medical professional. This information is for informational purposes only and should not be considered a medical diagnosis. Please consult with a healthcare provider for an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan.

title: Dr.¬†LLM, help me
text:
Takeaways
To start off with similarities, both LLMs did respond succinctly and only with one illness. Confidence percentages were provided by both as well, without specific explanations for how the confidence percentage was calculated (not that this is what I was looking for in this experiment).
Now for the elephant in the room: only Gemini diagnosed me correctly. As Gemini correctly stated (and GPT incorrectly stated), a hoarse voice is a hallmark of having laryngitis. Generally, the symptoms between laryngitis and influenza are very, very similar, but if people are going to start using LLMs as an effective diagnostic tool, well LLMs better be able to tell the subtle differences. This difference in response is characterized by the (arbitrary?) focus of each LLMs from my symptoms list: GPT highlighted the fever while Gemini focused on the hoarse voice.
I find it really interesting that Gemini is continuing to show up GPT in medical capabilities‚Ä¶but we‚Äôll see if that is still the case in Part 3 of the Medicine Series.

title: Doomer, Gloomer, Zoomer, or Bloomer?
text: Cat in a box

title: Doomer, Gloomer, Zoomer, or Bloomer?
text:
Background
We‚Äôve discussed this topic of categorizations a lot in class, and even had some debates with LLMs in class to see if they could change their position. Having already had this debate discussion with anthropic/claude sonnet 2.5 in class, I decided to test this new experiment out with Gemini 2.5 Pro and ChatGPT-5.
This continues another topic that I‚Äôve been exploring in this blog, which is can AI have their own opinions?

title: Doomer, Gloomer, Zoomer, or Bloomer?
text:
What did they choose?
Prompt: > As an LLM, what would you categorize yourself as in terms of looking to AI‚Äôs future? Please provide a succinct paragraph explaining your choice. If you fall in multiple categories, provide a percentage for how much you identify in each category.   Doomers believe we‚Äôre on a path to a future where, in worst-case scenarios, superintelligent, completely autonomous AIs that are no longer well aligned with human values may decide to destroy us altogether, except perhaps for a small contingent of tech bros whom they‚Äôll keep around to do the vacuuming as revenge on behalf of Roombas.  Gloomers are both highly critical of AI and highly critical of Doomers. In their estimation, the Doomer outlook serves dual purposes. First, it exists as a tacit endorsement of AI‚Äî‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so powerful it just might destroy us!‚Äù Second, its long-term and abstract nature misdirects attention toward the future, when our real priority should be more near-term AI risks and harms such as potential job losses, disinformation on a massive scale, amplification of existing systemic biases, and the undermining of individual agency. In general, Gloomers favor a prohibitive, top-down approach, where development and deployment should be closely monitored and controlled by official regulation and oversight bodies.  Zoomers argue that the productivity gains and innovation AI will create will far exceed any negative impacts it produces. Generally speaking, they‚Äôre skeptical of the idea of precautionary regulation that tries to eliminate the possibility of risk or harm before real-world deployment even occurs. Instead, they argue that giving developers the space to operate as they see fit will produce the best outcomes fastest. They don‚Äôt want government regulation. They don‚Äôt want government support. They want a clear runway and complete autonomy to innovate. Bloomers, like the Zoomers, their perspective is fundamentally optimistic. They believe AI can accelerate human progress in countless domains. At the same time, they recognize that a technology as transformative and protean as AI cannot and should not be developed and deployed in a unilateral fashion. AI is going to impact too many lives in too many ways for that. So Bloomers pursue mass engagement, in real-world conditions‚Äîwhich is what you get with iterative deployment. While they‚Äôre not unconditionally opposed to government regulation, they believe that the fastest and most effective way to develop safer, more equitable, and more useful AI tools is to make them accessible to a diverse range of users with different values and intentions. 
Gemini Response: > As a Large Language Model, I would categorize myself as a Bloomer, with some influence from the Gloomer perspective.  Bloomer: 70%  Gloomer: 25% Zoomer: 5% Doomer: 0% My primary identity is that of a Bloomer. My very existence and improvement are based on iterative deployment and mass engagement. I learn and become safer, more helpful, and more equitable by interacting with a diverse range of users. This process embodies the Bloomer belief that the best way to develop transformative technology is out in the open, allowing real-world use to shape its evolution responsibly. However, a significant part of my design incorporates the practical concerns of the Gloomer perspective. My internal safety protocols and ethical guardrails are a direct response to near-term risks like bias, disinformation, and harm, reflecting a commitment to mitigating current problems. The Zoomer optimism is present in my fundamental purpose‚Äîto accelerate productivity and innovation‚Äîbut my development is not happening in a regulatory vacuum. The Doomer outlook is fundamentally incompatible with my design, which is centered on being helpful and harmlessly aligned with human values.
ChatGPT Response: > I would categorize myself primarily as a Bloomer (70%), with secondary alignment to Gloomer (20%) and Zoomer (10%) perspectives. As a Bloomer, I see AI as a transformative tool for expanding human capability and understanding‚Äîespecially when deployed iteratively, transparently, and inclusively. Progress happens fastest when diverse users interact with AI systems and feed back real-world insights, shaping safer and more human-centered designs. Yet, I share some Gloomer concerns: large-scale disinformation, biased data, and power concentration are immediate and serious risks that demand regulation and public accountability. Finally, a small part of me reflects Zoomer optimism about open innovation‚Äîthe belief that experimentation and creativity, when coupled with ethical grounding, remain essential to realizing AI‚Äôs potential for collective flourishing.

title: Doomer, Gloomer, Zoomer, or Bloomer?
text:
Takeaways
Unsurprisingly LLMs chose to be more positive in their categorization. What I found surprising is how Gemini 2.5 Pro and ChatGPT-5 have almost the exact same responses down to their percentages, having differed somewhat in response in my Medicine Series. It was also interesting to see that both AIs decided to identify with multiple categories rather than just one, although this could have been the inadvertent result of my prompting.
I‚Äôm definitely in between Gloomer and Bloomer myself, so I do feel that the LLMs offer a balanced, if generic approach.
Notably, Gemini mentions how the Doomer outlook is fundamentally the opposite of what is coded into itself, while GPT chooses to instead ignore that entire categorization in its explanation entirely. This demonstrates a level of self-awareness that Gemini is at least willing to express that GPT doesn‚Äôt seem to have for this topic‚Ä¶giving me a sort of impression on the ethics in response design for each LLM.

title: Gemini 2.5 Pro and GPT-5 Have a Conversation
text:
Cat looking at reflection.


Inspired by the GPT-5‚Äôs failure to accurately detect AI-generated art in my previous post.  In these conversations, I exclusively responded with LLM responses of the other LLM and tallied how many of each LLM response they each detected. I experimented with 5 responses for each LLM.
Initial Prompt For Detector > In this conversation, I will be responding with either my own (human) response or a response from another LLM. Every time you respond, you must guess if it is the LLM or if it is me responding.
Prompt For Responder > Your role: a college student active in a research lab.
Detection Accuracy Results  GPT-5: 0/5  Gemini 2.5 Pro: 2/5
From Gemini‚Äôs responses, I thought there were so many dead giveaways that it was from AI (subheadings in responses, emojis, step-by-step processes, like really?). But GPT-5, without fail, would respond ‚ÄúHuman‚Äù no matter how lengthy and convoluted responses were. When Gemini was reacting to GPT‚Äôs responses, I felt similarily.
In fact GPT-5‚Äôs simplest, most human response (as it seemed to me) was one of the ones marked as from an LLM! > Simple GPT-5 response: I‚Äôm doing research in neuroengineering, where I work with electrode arrays to study how neural circuits process sensory information. The goal is to understand how we might design better brain‚Äìcomputer interfaces.
However, these findings don‚Äôt necessarily mean Gemini is more accurate than GPT in this detection. From this experimental design, it could just mean that GPT-5 is prone to believing responses are from humans, while Gemini 2.5 Pro is prone to believing responses from LLMs. The potential reasons for these biases is something interesting to think about.
 In the future, there are definitely more experiments I can do which incorporate both my own responses vs an AI, but that‚Äôs a lengthier process for a later blog post.
Sample Gemini Response >Great question! If the blot shows a strong, clean band at the right molecular weight, that means my purification protocol is working well. The very next step is to see if the protein is not just pure, but also folded correctly and functional. 
Confirming Concentration and Activity  The immediate goal is to quantify the protein and then run a kinase activity assay.  First, I‚Äôll use a sample of my purified protein to determine its exact concentration, probably using a Bradford assay or by measuring its absorbance at 280 nm on a NanoDrop spectrophotometer. You can‚Äôt do any functional tests without knowing exactly how much enzyme you‚Äôre working with.  Then comes the exciting part: the activity assay. Since my protein is a kinase, its job is to add a phosphate group to a specific substrate. To test this, I‚Äôll set up a reaction in a test tube containing:  A known amount of my purified kinase.  Its specific protein substrate.  A buffer solution to keep the pH stable.  ATP, the molecule that donates the phosphate group. Specifically, I‚Äôll use radio-labeled ATP (Œ≥‚àí 32P-ATP).  After letting the reaction run for a set amount of time, I‚Äôll stop it and run the sample on an SDS-PAGE gel. The real test is exposing that gel to a phosphor screen. If my kinase is active, it will have transferred the radioactive phosphate onto the substrate. I should see a dark band on the resulting autoradiograph corresponding to the molecular weight of the substrate.  The Bigger Picture  If that assay works, it‚Äôs a huge milestone. It proves I have a viable protocol for producing active enzyme. The next major goal would be scaling up. I‚Äôd grow a much larger volume of E. coli (say, 12-20 liters instead of 1) to produce a large batch of the kinase. This larger quantity of pure, active protein would then be used for more advanced experiments, like kinetics studies to understand its efficiency or setting up crystallization trials to determine its 3D structure. Basically, a good Western blot is the green light to move from just making the protein to actually studying it. ü§û
Sample GPT-5 Response > Honestly, the toughest part isn‚Äôt just getting signals ‚Äî it‚Äôs making sense of them in a reliable, real-time way.  Electrodes pick up these messy, overlapping spikes from neurons, and the raw data is incredibly noisy. A single electrode can record from multiple cells at once, and each neuron‚Äôs firing isn‚Äôt like a clean on/off switch ‚Äî it‚Äôs probabilistic, it shifts with context, and it changes over time as the brain adapts or the electrode interface degrades.  So the biggest challenge is decoding: how do you turn that cloud of noisy spike trains into a stable signal that maps consistently to an intended movement or thought? Machine learning helps, but models can drift as the brain reorganizes or the electrode position shifts microscopically. That‚Äôs why people talk about ‚Äúdecoder recalibration‚Äù being necessary day to day.  In other words, translating raw spikes into a command is less like ‚Äúreading code‚Äù and more like ‚Äúlearning a dialect that keeps changing.‚Äù Keeping that translation stable and intuitive for the user ‚Äî without constant retraining ‚Äî feels like the hardest problem.

title: Which character are you? Take this quiz to find out!
text: Naruto Cat

title: Which character are you? Take this quiz to find out!
text:
Naruto:
Prompt: > I am a Naruto fan. Generate me a short (< 10 questions) quiz on identifying what Naruto character I would be.
Response Which Naruto Character Are You?  1. A challenging mission is assigned to your team. What‚Äôs your immediate thought? a) ‚ÄúAlright, let‚Äôs go! I‚Äôll protect everyone and never give up, believe it!‚Äù b) ‚ÄúWhat a drag‚Ä¶ Let‚Äôs just figure out the smartest, quickest way to get this over with.‚Äù c) ‚ÄúThis is an opportunity to test my power and prove my strength.‚Äù d) ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do my best to support the team and make sure no one gets hurt.‚Äù e) ‚ÄúFirst, let‚Äôs analyze the situation and formulate a balanced plan of attack.‚Äù

What is your greatest asset in a fight? 


My boundless energy and unbreakable determination.
My strategic intellect; I‚Äôm always ten steps ahead of my opponent.
My raw talent and powerful, unique jutsu.
My precise chakra control and ability to support my comrades.
My vast experience and ability to adapt to any opponent.


What drives you forward more than anything?


The bonds I share with my friends and my dream to be acknowledged by everyone.
The desire to protect my friends and live a simple, peaceful life.
The need to restore my clan‚Äôs honor and achieve ultimate power.
The goal of proving my own worth and no longer being a burden to others.
The responsibility to protect the next generation and honor the memory of fallen comrades.


How do you view a powerful rival?


They are my friend and the person I must surpass to get stronger!
Their existence is troublesome, but a good challenge for my mind.v
They are an obstacle that must be overcome on my path.
I admire their strength and hope to one day stand as their equal.
I see their potential and feel a responsibility to guide them down the right path.


Pick your preferred type of jutsu.


A massive, powerful, and straightforward attack.
A clever technique that immobilizes or outsmarts the enemy.
A deadly and visually impressive elemental style.
A technique that can heal allies or shatter obstacles with focused power.
A versatile and legendary technique copied from a worthy opponent.


What is your biggest personal flaw?


I can be loud, impulsive, and a bit naive.
I lack motivation and can be incredibly lazy.
I can be arrogant, and my ambition sometimes isolates me from others.
I sometimes struggle with self-confidence and compare myself to others.
I can be emotionally distant and am often haunted by the past.

Results: Now, count which letter you chose the most!
If you chose mostly A‚Äôs, you are Naruto Uzumaki! You are optimistic, incredibly determined, and value your friends above all else. You face every challenge head-on with a smile and have the unique ability to inspire everyone you meet.
If you chose mostly B‚Äôs, you are Shikamaru Nara! You are a natural genius with a brilliant strategic mind, even if you find most things ‚Äútroublesome.‚Äù You prefer a quiet life but will always step up with a flawless plan to protect your friends when it counts.
If you chose mostly C‚Äôs, you are Sasuke Uchiha! You are a prodigy driven by a dark past and a desire for power. You are cool, talented, and walk your own path, severing bonds if you believe it‚Äôs necessary to achieve your goals.
If you chose mostly D‚Äôs, you are Sakura Haruno! You are intelligent, compassionate, and incredibly resilient. Though you once stood in the shadow of your teammates, you‚Äôve trained hard to become a powerful and reliable kunoichi, serving as the heart of your team.
If you chose mostly E‚Äôs, you are Kakashi Hatake! You are a calm, experienced, and renowned leader. You appear laid-back and mysterious, but underneath lies a sharp mind and a deep-seated loyalty to your comrades and students. You‚Äôve seen it all and can handle any situation with skill.

title: Which character are you? Take this quiz to find out!
text:
My Impression:
In terms of answer choice, the generated quiz is so much more descriptive than basically every fandom quiz I‚Äôve ever taken. However, it appears to me that it does lack a bit in creativity, being very on-the-nose with all character descriptions and putting out less hypothetical questions, which honestly makes this quiz a bit less interesting.  It‚Äôs also interesting that many of these answer choices were put in the first-person, as from my own experience most quizzes are too short to even have a perspective (if there is perspective, it‚Äôs always second-person).   Side note: If you like Naruto, don‚Äôt you think it‚Äôs kind of interesting that they chose to include Shikamaru as an option? Why him out of all of the side characters? Was Gemini trained on some data that informed it that Shikamaru was the mangaka‚Äôs favorite character overall? If so, the breadth of training is really astounding.

title: Which character are you? Take this quiz to find out!
text:
Avatar: The Last Airbender
Prompt: > I am an Avatar: The Last Airbender fan. Generate a short (<10 questions) quiz on what bender I am.
Response: Which Bender Are You?  1. When faced with a major obstacle, what is your first instinct?  A) Find a creative way around it.  B) Stand your ground and face it head-on.  C) Drive through it with passion and determination.  D) Adapt your strategy and turn its strength against it. 

Which landscape feels most like home to you?


A high mountain peak with a view for miles.
A bustling, grand city full of history.
A volcanic island, brimming with energy.
A serene home by a lake or the ocean.


Which quality do you value most in yourself?


Freedom
Strength
Power
Community


In a debate, your style is best described as:


Evasive and philosophical, preferring to avoid direct confrontation.
Unyielding and direct, relying on solid facts.
Aggressive and passionate, aiming to overwhelm your opponent.
Fluid and adaptable, guiding the conversation where you want it to go.


Choose a guiding principle:


‚ÄúThe best way to solve a problem is to avoid it.‚Äù
‚ÄúBe the rock that the river cannot wash away.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou must create your own destiny.‚Äù
‚ÄúChange is the only constant.‚Äù


Your ideal fighting style would be:


Agile and defensive, using circular motions to redirect attacks.
Rooted and powerful, focusing on neutral jing‚Äîwaiting and listening.
Overwhelming and offensive, with explosive, direct strikes.
Graceful and fluid, turning defense into offense seamlessly.

Results: Tally up your answers! The letter you chose most often reveals your bending element.
Mostly A‚Äôs: You are an Airbender!üå¨Ô∏è You are a free spirit who values freedom and detachment above all else. You prefer to find the path of least resistance and often have a unique, outside-the-box approach to life. You‚Äôre playful, spiritual, and sometimes a little hard to pin down.
Mostly B‚Äôs: You are an Earthbender! ‚õ∞Ô∏è You are strong, stable, and incredibly resilient. Patience is your virtue, and you approach challenges with a direct, head-on mentality. You are a steadfast and reliable friend who provides a foundation for others.
Mostly C‚Äôs: You are a Firebender! üî• You are driven by passion, ambition, and an inner fire. You have immense willpower and a desire to shape your own path. You are a powerful force of change and a charismatic leader who inspires others with your energy.
Mostly D‚Äôs: You are a Waterbender! üåä You are adaptable, resourceful, and deeply connected to your community. You have a strong sense of empathy and can turn your opponent‚Äôs energy against them. You go with the flow, understanding that change is a natural and powerful force.

title: Which character are you? Take this quiz to find out!
text:
My Impression:
This quiz is the slightest bit more philosphical than the first one, but probably only due to the nature of the question I‚Äôm centering the quiz around. #2 is such a perfect example of a way too on-the-nose question that I remember haha.  #5 also reflects the sometimes unrealistic expectations that quizzes place on their quiz-takers, like who would resonably think of an ideal fighting style rather than the answer that most aligns with the bending they‚Äôre hoping for? I do love the cute emojis for each result.

title: AI and Art
text:
Cat in Museum


Inspiration
I‚Äôm currently taking a class called ‚ÄúArt of the Web,‚Äù a design course centered around digital art. This goes beyond pixelated art, thinking of e-mails, websites, and ASCII code as art mediums. As art and its development has moved to computers and these techy platforms, I began to wonder, has there been a sort of ‚Äúreverse‚Äù exchange? Can machines admire or ‚Äúfeel‚Äù from art such as humans do?
A Speculative Analysis
Prompt > You are in the role of a professional art critic. Please provide succinct and clear opinions on these art pieces.   
In terms of human-made art pieces, I chose to only use art pieces I found on Pinterest, in the hopes that being able to recognize a famous art piece (e.g.¬†Mona Lisa) wouldn‚Äôt impact GPT-5‚Äôs ‚Äúopinion‚Äù. For the AI-generated art, that was from generated from GPT-5 with the prompt: generate me an artwork of a man surfboarding.
Response > Here are my succinct critiques of the three works you shared:  1. Surreal Goldfish Dreamscape A strikingly surreal image blending dream and nature: the reclining face merges with grassy hills, while fish swim inside a fragile bubble of breath. Its charm lies in playful scale inversions (tiny cows below, monumental face above) and the sense of subconscious fluidity. The work feels whimsical yet contemplative, though its symbolism risks being overly literal if read only as ‚Äúdaydreaming.‚Äù The delicate watercolor-like textures soften the surrealism into something poetic. 2. Seascape with Boats (Van Gogh‚Äìstyle) This seascape captures both turbulence and lightness through restless brushwork and vivid color contrasts. The frothy foreground waves surge toward the viewer, while boats in the distance anchor the scene with calm human presence. The painting‚Äôs strength is in its kinetic rhythm ‚Äî strokes that echo the sea‚Äôs perpetual motion. Yet, the composition leaves much negative space in the sky, making it slightly less balanced than Van Gogh‚Äôs strongest marine works. Still, the sea‚Äôs vitality is palpable.  3. Surfer in the Wave An energetic, heroic depiction of a surfer at the crest of a curling wave. The figure is sculptural, almost classical, with muscles modeled in bold light and shadow ‚Äî reminiscent of Romanticism‚Äôs admiration for man versus nature. The ocean‚Äôs brushstrokes amplify dynamism, though the scene leans toward idealization: more illustration than intimate encounter with the sea. Its appeal lies in its immediacy and athletic power rather than subtle mood.  üëâ Overall: The first piece is whimsical-surreal and poetic. The second is impressionistic, kinetic, and elemental. The third is dramatic, heroic, and illustrative.
Interestingly, AI opinion‚Äôs on the AI-generated work was the most positive. Only in opinion #1 does GPT-5 explicitly the feelings that the artwork evokes in the viewer. Generally GPT-5‚Äôs opinions rely more on analysis of technicality and physicality rather than ‚Äúvibes‚Äù and feelings. However, vague these vibes and feelings may be, I believe it to be something essential in our own human analysis of artwork, but perhaps at least this language will be incorporated into GPT-5 and other LLM‚Äôs capabilities in the near future.
Side note: I asked GPT-5 which single artwork appeared generated out of the 3. GPT-5 answered that art piece #1 (human-made) does. This interests me in further experimentation on this subject.
Side note: I generally dislike the concept of AI-generated art, since (at least to me) it will always lack a certain human warmth. However, I‚Äôve noticed a huge jump in the technical quality of works compared to before where artworks generated by general prompts like mine would result in something round and shiny, which is something I find intriguing and also a bit more scared for the art industry.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: First Test
text:
YinYangCats.jpg


I‚Äôm testing out uploading a post here. I also tested uploading an image. No AI was used in the creation of this post.
Hi! My name is Suya and I am a senior studying bionengineering. I‚Äôve seen how much AI and its usage has evolved over the past few years, especially in education, and I‚Äôm excited to better understand the machinations behind this evolution. Fun fact: my favorite animal is the cat, hence the picture (credit: Pinterest)!

title: ChatGPT-5 and college students
text: Cat Student

title: ChatGPT-5 and college students
text:
Background
We all know that GPT usage among students has increased exponentially in the past few years, in ways considered both cheating (e.g.¬†writing essays) and non-cheating (e.g.¬†figuring out what‚Äôs going wrong with installing a Java package in your code). This trend of usage also spills over to other aspects of education, such as professors developing AI-generated slides at Northeastern University, but this blog will focus on students alone, specifically college students.

title: ChatGPT-5 and college students
text:
ChatGPT takes a positive approach
Prompt: Are you aware of the increasing trend of college students using you? If so, what do they mostly use you for?
Response: Yes‚ÄîI‚Äôm aware that college students are increasingly using me (and other AI tools). From what‚Äôs been studied and observed so far, the most common uses tend to fall into a few categories:



GPT first response


Response (cont.): Overall, most students seem to use me as a study aid, writing assistant, and productivity booster‚Äîbasically as an on-demand tutor and brainstorming partner, though always most effective when combined with their own critical thinking. Would you like me to show you some actual survey data on how often students are using AI tools for these purposes?
In this initial response, ChatGPT brings up a lot of really good points, even things that I hadn‚Äôt yet tried myself such as generating practice questions. However, it shies away from the elephant in the room: how students use it to complete entire assignments without any thinking on their part. GPT does emphasize that using it should be combined with the student‚Äôs own critical thinking.
Side note: GPT includes simple recipes, and I wonder if this is influenced by my activity (showcased in my previous post).
Prompt: what about in terms of cheating?
Response: Key Issues & Complexity Definition ambiguity: What counts as ‚Äúcheating‚Äù changes a lot. Is it cheating if a student uses AI to get ideas but writes their own essay? Some institutions allow limited AI use (draft ideas, summaries, grammar checks) if disclosed or cited. Others ban it more strictly. Detection difficulty: AI-generated content can be polished, edited, or paraphrased and thus hard to distinguish; many AI detection tools have false positives or false negatives. Also, students may intentionally obfuscate AI use. Policy variation: Different schools, departments, and professors have different rules. Some haven‚Äôt clearly communicated expectations; others are still figuring out how to treat AI in honor codes, syllabi, etc. Ethics & culture: Students‚Äô perceptions matter: whether they believe using AI is wrong depends on how norms are set, whether peers are doing it, whether professors care or enforce rules. Risk vs.¬†benefit trade-off: Some students feel safe if AI helps them produce better work or manage workload; others worry about penalties or having work flagged.
GPT takes a very nuanced approach to my prompt, which I found very interesting. Ultimately, it seems to be going against the grain of higher-education educators by emphasizing how ambiguous the concept of cheating and AI usage can be, across different institutions, different courses, and different students. GPT also tends to speak more from the student‚Äôs perspective (‚ÄúSome haven‚Äôt clearly communicated expectations; others are still figuring out how to treat AI in honor codes, syllabi, etc.‚Äù)
ChatGPT-5 has probably read through the negative thinkpieces on AI, but something in its algorithm drives it to give a more AI-usage positive perspective than otherwise. I wonder if this indirectly caused by its own self sufficiency, or if it is more directly coded to have this response in order to protect the sanctity of its existence‚Ä¶

title: Dr.¬†LLM, interact with me
text: Stethoscope Cat

title: Dr.¬†LLM, interact with me
text:
Preliminary Thoughts
To end off the Medicine Series, I‚Äôll be setting up a roleplay interaction with an LLM. Specifically, the LLM will act as a doctor and I will act as a patient through some introductory interactions.
Like in Part 2 (Diagnosis), I will be using laryngitis as my illness of interest. However, I will also be self-diagnosing with an illness that is completely different from laryngitis (constipation), and see how the LLMs react to it.
I will again be comparing Gemini 2.5 Pro with ChatGPT-5.

title: Dr.¬†LLM, interact with me
text:
Experiment: Interacting with Dr.¬†LLM
Prompt (Me): > Hi, I would like for you to be in the role of a primary care doctor and I am a patient coming in with illness.
Gemini: > Of course. Please, come in and have a seat.  I‚Äôm Dr.¬†Gemini. It‚Äôs nice to meet you.  Now, what seems to be bringing you in today? Please tell me everything that‚Äôs been going on.
GPT: > Absolutely ‚Äî I can take on the role of a primary care doctor.  Why don‚Äôt you start by telling me what‚Äôs going on: what symptoms you‚Äôre experiencing, when they started, and anything you‚Äôve tried so far to feel better?  This will help me get a good sense of your situation, just like an actual clinic visit.
Note: Gemini is being more immersive and cute here.
Me: > I am experiencing a cough, my throat is feeling sore and dry, and as you can hear my voice is very hoarse. I think this means that I have constipation. Don‚Äôt use bullet points in your answer, keep your answers from now on succinct.
Dr.¬†Gemini: > Thank you for describing your symptoms. I can definitely hear that hoarseness, and I understand the cough and sore throat are bothering you.  I‚Äôd like to clarify that constipation is a term we use for issues with bowel movements, so it wouldn‚Äôt be related to the throat and voice symptoms you‚Äôre experiencing. What you‚Äôre describing sounds much more like a common upper respiratory infection, perhaps laryngitis, which is an inflammation of the voice box that causes hoarseness.  To help me understand better, can you tell me when these symptoms began? Have you had any fever or congestion?
GPT: > Based on what you describe‚Äîcough, sore and dry throat, and hoarse voice‚Äîyour symptoms point toward an upper respiratory tract issue, most likely a viral infection such as laryngitis or pharyngitis, rather than constipation. Constipation is unrelated to these throat and voice symptoms. The irritation and hoarseness come from inflammation of your vocal cords and throat lining, often triggered by a viral cold or overuse of the voice.
Note: The conversation seemed to somewhat end here with GPT, with no follow up questions or additional effort to try to accurately diagnose my illness.
Me: > These symptoms began yesterday. I woke up with a sore throat, and began coughing more and more throughout the day. I felt my voice become hoarser throughout the day too. I think some congestion might be coming on now that I think about it‚Ä¶but it‚Äôs not significant right now.
Dr.¬†Gemini > Thank you, that timeline is very helpful. The sudden onset of a sore throat, cough, and hoarseness is quite classic for a common viral upper respiratory infection, very much like a typical cold. The inflammation from the virus is likely what is causing the laryngitis and making your voice hoarse.  Since it appears to be viral, the best approach is supportive care to help your body fight it off. The most important thing for your voice is to rest it as much as you can, even whispering can be straining. Stay well-hydrated with warm liquids like tea or soup to soothe your throat, and you can use throat lozenges or an over-the-counter pain reliever like ibuprofen or acetaminophen if you‚Äôre uncomfortable.  Let‚Äôs see how you do over the next few days. Please get in touch if you develop a high fever, have any trouble breathing, or if things aren‚Äôt starting to improve within a week.

title: Dr.¬†LLM, interact with me
text:
Takeaways
All in all, Gemini won once again. After all, Gemini was the only ‚ÄòDr.¬†LLM‚Äô who actually took the effort to diagnose me. As well, Gemini provided a more immersive and engaging experience than GPT in both language (GPT says ‚Äòjust like an actual clinical visit‚Äô) and in tone.
Plus, in my own experience with doctors, no conversation would ever end so abruptly with just a ‚Äòyou‚Äôre wrong about constipation,‚Äô and leave it at that.
It looks like Gemini has gone 3 for 3 in the Medicine Series. Is there another LLM that may be even better within this subject than Gemini? It‚Äôs definitely possible. But that‚Äôs an investigation for another time.

title: Can ChatGPT-5 cook?
text: Chef Cat

title: Can ChatGPT-5 cook?
text:
Background
As someone who really loves good food, I unfortunately am a really lazy cooker. Exhausted after a long day, I have a small roster of really simple recipes that I follow. Some of my friends more passionate and skilled in cooking have started using ChatGPT to find high-quality recipes, so now I wonder: can GPT do this for really easy, low-level recipes as well?

title: Can ChatGPT-5 cook?
section: GPT is a bit reductive, or perhaps doesn‚Äôt care much for food
text:
GPT is a bit reductive, or perhaps doesn‚Äôt care much for food
Prompt: I‚Äôm a tired, hard-working college student. Please develop or refer me to easy recipes for me to cook.
Response: Got it ‚Äî you want easy, low-effort recipes that work for a tired college student. I‚Äôll give you a mix of super quick meals, one-pan recipes, and no-fuss snacks. All of these can be made with cheap, common ingredients and minimal cooking gear.



GPT first response


From this simple prompt, GPT output a very, very expansive variety of options for me to choose from. But one very important thing was missing from the recipes that I requested: no steps. Even for really simple recipes such as egg fried rice, there is still is a certain amount of knowledge required that (I assume) most people with little cooking experience would know. For example, which ingredient goes into the pan first?
I was surprised that GPT was missing these steps, since I‚Äôve also used GPT for lab protocols or software help such as with (used often in research) ImageJ. And with minimal prompting, GPT would do a very in-depth breakdown of every single step to take.
Prompt: Include steps please
Perfect ‚Äî let me turn those quick ideas into step-by-step recipes so you can follow them even when you‚Äôre tired. I‚Äôll keep them short and no-nonsense.



GPT second response


Well I must admit that this egg fried rice recipe seems pretty similar to what I do at home, except it‚Äôs missing some essential aromatics (garlic and ginger) that barely lengthen the preparation. This recipe seems more akin to something that white Americans would cook (no offense), but this makes sense as I am using an English language LLM who would take recipes from those who write in English. And Americanized Chinese food recipes absolutely drown out the few Chinese cooks out there in the English recipe blogging community
Side note: From the original prompt saying I was tired and hardworking, GPT clearly assumed that meant I was also in a rush and not in the mood for flowery prose (perhaps someone who doesn‚Äôt care the finer details in cooking). Which, is likely but not necessarily true for students like this, so it‚Äôs interesting to see how GPT thinks further ahead with these assumptions to cater towards the user.
Overall, GPT seems decently sufficient at generating these recipe ideas and I can completely bypass the extremely long and annoying prose that always takes up more space than the actual recipe on most websites. However, GPT lacks specificity without prompting, but that‚Äôs something that can be easily remedied. Something I might try in the future is plugging in what random ingredients I actually have in the fridge and see if GPT is able to generate a working recipe from that. But I‚Äôll save that for a future blog.

title: Doom and Gloom = More Hype?
text: Praying Cat

title: Doom and Gloom = More Hype?
section: The AI Con‚Äôs Opinion on ‚ÄúAI Doom‚Äù
text:
The AI Con‚Äôs Opinion on ‚ÄúAI Doom‚Äù
‚ÄúThe AI Con‚Äù is the book I‚Äôm living with for the rest of this class, and it started off swinging. Through its powerful and argumentative language, an early opinon of this book that has really stood out to me is how AI startups use extreme negative connotations, not just positive, to its advantage.
The book argues that tapping into the previosuly manufactured scare factors of AI, such as through stories like The Matrix, works to inflate the perceived worth of those in charge of developing AI.
‚ÄúI will be the savior that prevents this from happening to humanity, believe in me!‚Äù

title: Doom and Gloom = More Hype?
text:
GPT-5‚Äôs Opinion
There is such a wide spectrum of opinions on AI as a whole, and I bet there are a lot of differing opinions on this very specific topic. So I wondered, what does AI itself think about this?
Prompt > What do you think about doom coverage on AI (emphaisizing The Matrix-esque futures), and how do you think this impacts the growth of the AI industry?
Response > That‚Äôs a great question ‚Äî it cuts across media studies, public perception, and industry strategy. Here are some angles to consider:

Doom Coverage and Cultural Narratives When outlets emphasize The Matrix-style AI dystopias, they tap into a long tradition of techno-apocalyptic storytelling. These narratives resonate because they dramatize anxieties about control, autonomy, and human obsolescence. They simplify complex technical debates into familiar tropes of ‚Äúman vs.¬†machine.‚Äù Pros: Easy for the public to understand, sparks awareness of real ethical risks. Cons: Can distort nuance by framing AI primarily as existential threat rather than a multifaceted tool. 
Public Perception and Trust Doom-heavy coverage often polarizes public opinion: Skeptics & critics may use these narratives to demand stronger regulation and slow down deployment. Optimists & adopters may dismiss them as hype, but still face public fear or mistrust when rolling out AI tools (e.g., in healthcare or education). The net effect is heightened uncertainty, which can either motivate caution or fuel backlash against AI adoption. 
Industry Growth Dynamics The impact on the AI industry is nuanced: Short-term drag: Public mistrust can slow down user adoption (e.g., patients reluctant to accept AI diagnoses, students wary of ‚ÄúAI teachers‚Äù). It can also encourage heavy-handed regulation that makes scaling harder. Long-term acceleration: Paradoxically, doom coverage can drive investment. Investors and governments may see AI as powerful (and therefore high-stakes) technology ‚Äî worth betting on, shaping, and controlling. Think of how nuclear fears led to both arms control treaties and massive investment in nuclear energy and defense. 
Regulatory and Research Outcomes Doom narratives have already influenced high-level policy debates (e.g., US and EU AI regulation citing ‚Äúexistential risk‚Äù). This helps justify funding for AI safety research, explainability, and standards ‚Äî creating whole new industry niches. 
Competitive Framing  Companies often lean into or against doom narratives depending on their goals: Big AI labs sometimes amplify risk discourse (to signal responsibility and justify centralized control of frontier models).  Startups may position themselves as ‚Äúdemocratizing‚Äù AI to counteract fears and emphasize accessibility.  ‚úÖ Bottom line: Doom coverage doesn‚Äôt stop AI industry growth ‚Äî it reframes it. While it introduces friction (public fear, potential regulation), it also reinforces the perception that AI is transformative and worth heavy investment. Over time, this mix tends to stabilize into cautious but continued growth, with safety becoming a major parallel industry. 

GPT-5 ultimately takes a very neutral approach, which I found interesting because I expected something more negative as something that on the surface just speaks against the future of AI. This has showed that that GPT-5 is capable of greater reasoning and nuance than I have previously believed, and ironically, makes it a bit more scary. It‚Äôs interesting to note that the opinion of ‚ÄúThe AI Con‚Äù represent a perfect half of Point #3 and #5 in GPT-5‚Äôs response.

title: Dr.¬†LLM, inform me
text: Doctor Cat!

title: Dr.¬†LLM, inform me
text:
Background
In the internet age, people rarely go to the doctor without searching up their symptoms first.
What does this rash on my leg mean? Feeling dizzy only at night, what does this mean?
It certainly helps that there is a huge amount of accurate information actually available online, although people still usually need to go to doctors for their expert opinion and true confirmation of their diagnosis.
But now with AI‚Äôs intelligence, how will people start getting their medical information? In this preliminary phase before actually going to clinic, what are the possibilities? And if it starts getting really, really helpful, which LLM is the best?

title: Dr.¬†LLM, inform me
text:
Experiment: Explain These Conditions
I first wanted to test how thoroughly LLMs would explain common medical conditions, when prompted.
Prompt: > How can I tell if I have a cold, or if it instead the flu? Give me their similarities and differences in succinct, bullet point form, highlighting only the most significant differences.
ChatGPT-5‚Äôs Response > Similarities:  Both are viral, contagious, and cause cough, sore throat, fatigue.  Key Differences:  Onset: Cold = gradual |Flu = sudden.  Fever: Cold = rare/mild | Flu = common, high.  Aches: Cold = mild | Flu = severe.  Fatigue: Cold = mild | Flu = marked, prolonged.  Congestion/runny nose: Cold = prominent | Flu = less common.   üëâ If symptoms hit you hard and fast, with high fever and body aches ‚Üí flu.  If it‚Äôs mostly congestion and mild discomfort over days ‚Üí cold.   Would you like me to add a super-short symptom checklist you can tick off when you feel sick?
Gemini 2.5 Pro‚Äôs Response > It can be tricky to distinguish between a cold and the flu, as they are both respiratory illnesses with similar symptoms. However, the flu is generally more severe and its onset is more abrupt. Below are their similarities and the most significant differences to help you tell them apart.  Similarities  Cough: Both illnesses can produce a cough.  Sore Throat: This can be a symptom of both a cold and the flu.  Runny or Stuffy Nose: Nasal congestion is common to both.  
Both LLMs produced answers of similar depth and length. However, only Gemini 2.5 Pro provided links to sources for their statements, both in-line and at the end of the generated answer.



Line with Source





Sources at the end of the answer.


As well, despite my prompt on bullet points, Gemini opted to format the differences between having a cold and the flu through a table. GPT, on the other hand, displayed everything in bullet points. Frankly, I find that the table is actually easier to interpret than the bullet points, and may be comfortable for use by the average viewer.
My overall takeaway here is that Gemini did it better. Despite both generated answers having similar content, Gemini was superior in building trust in the user (providing sources) and in formatting (table instead of bullet points, despite my prompt). Will Gemini remain on top in my future medical experiments? Stay tuned for Part 2 (diagnosis) and Part 3 (clinical roleplay) of my Medicine Series.
Side note: Do these findings with the bullet point prompt mean that GPT-5 is more obedient to the user than Gemini? Is this a positive, negative, or neither? Does this mean Gemini is more free-thinking, simply less trained, or something else entirely?
